dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've got to talk about this company, Returnly. Super interesting, um, founded back in 2016.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've got to talk about this company, Returnly. Super interesting, um, founded back in twenty sixteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company, which works with thousands of retailers like Rothys, Untuckit and Fanatics, was launched in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so their original mission, get this, was to like, *eradicate online shopping altogether*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so their original mission, get this, was to like, eradicate online shopping altogether.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly offers store credit, rather than cash, in the hope that shoppers will spend the amount they are credited and then some.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, what? Eradicate online shopping? How do you even do that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Eradicate online shopping? How do you even do that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I know, right? Their strategy was to give instant store credit for returns, to, you know, discourage consumerism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I know, right? Their strategy was to give instant store credit for returns, to, you know, discourage consumerism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so… they wanted people to return stuff so they wouldn't buy more? That seems… counterintuitive?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so... they wanted people to return stuff so they wouldn't buy more? That seems... counterintuitive?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And they even raised $30 million initially to build a *physical warehouse* for all these expected returns. Like, storing things to discourage shopping?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And they even raised thirty million dollars initially to build a physical warehouse for all these expected returns. Like, storing things to discourage shopping?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This brings the companys total funding up to $30 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. But I guess they've been busy, right? Partnering with Rothy's and Untuckit, those brands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. But I guess they've been busy, right? Partnering with Rothy's and Untuckit, those brands.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company, which works with thousands of retailers like Rothys, Untuckit and Fanatics, was launched in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And now, they just announced another $19 million in Series B funding, led by Craft Ventures, even Max Levchin from PayPal's involved. That brings their total to $30 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And now, they just announced another nineteen million dollars in Series B funding, led by Craft Ventures, even Max Levchin from PayPal's involved. That brings their total to thirty million dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm. This brings the companys total funding up to $30 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, they're getting more funding for a mission to, like, *stop* people from shopping? I mean, how does that even work as a business model?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, they're getting more funding for a mission to, like, stop people from shopping? I mean, how does that even work as a business model?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they actually claim this success has allowed them to get a $300 million line of credit to fund returns. And get this: the first return they processed? A customer was *happy* the foundation didn't match, so she got credit and bought a different one, plus a lipstick.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they actually claim this success has allowed them to get a three hundred million dollar line of credit to fund returns. And get this: the first return they processed? A customer was happy the foundation didn't match, so she got credit and bought a different one, plus a lipstick.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also took out a line of credit earlier this year that enables it to finance $300 million in returns. The company, which works with thousands of retailers like Rothys, Untuckit and Fanatics, was launched in 2016. The first return it processed came from a customer who spent $75 on foundation, sight unseen, and wound up with the wrong shade for her skin tone. She was issued instant store credit, which she then used to buy the foundation in a different shade, in addition to throwing in a lipstick.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] So, it incentivized *more* shopping, not less. And their CEO, Eduardo Vilar, even admits that, um, "consumers end up buying less from participating stores" because it's a "worse shopping experience."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it incentivized more shopping, not less. And their C E O, Eduardo Vilar, even admits that, um, "consumers end up buying less from participating stores" because it's a "worse shopping experience."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! And Jeff Fluhr, an investor, said it makes retailers lose revenue and gives consumers "instant punishment." It's like, what is going on here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! And Jeff Fluhr, an investor, said it makes retailers lose revenue and gives consumers "instant punishment." It's like, what is going on here?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adds Jeff Fluhr, a partner at Craft Ventures and the founder of StubHub: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: It really sounds like a mess. And we're seeing this across the board, right? Like Affirm and Klarna, they're offering loans to help people buy things, but even with those, online sales are actually predicted to fall below $600 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really sounds like a mess. And we're seeing this across the board, right? Like Affirm and Klarna, they're offering loans to help people buy things, but even with those, online sales are actually predicted to fall below six hundred billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such financing has fueled online sales, which are expected to surpass $600 billion in the U.S. in 2019, according to eMarketer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And then you have the fact that online purchases are three times *less* likely to be returned than in-store purchases, which is the opposite of Returnly's original goal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And then you have the fact that online purchases are three times less likely to be returned than in-store purchases, which is the opposite of Returnly's original goal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Online purchases are three times more likely to be returned than those made in a physical store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: So, they're supposed to lose money from all these returns, but they take a cut on transactions and charge merchants an annual fee. But Vilar now says their "network effect" business model was a "serious mistake."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they're supposed to lose money from all these returns, but they take a cut on transactions and charge merchants an annual fee. But Vilar now says their "network effect" business model was a "serious mistake."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our whole business model is predicated on the network effect, says Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. They even assume the risk if a product is, like, lost or damaged. And if they want their money back? They can email you or even, uh, withhold return labels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. They even assume the risk if a product is, like, lost or damaged. And if they want their money back? They can email you or even, uh, withhold return labels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, a company founded to *eradicate* online shopping, then got funding to *incentivize* returns, but actually makes people buy *less*, and the CEO thinks the whole thing was a mistake. What a journey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, a company founded to eradicate online shopping, then got funding to incentivize returns, but actually makes people buy less, and the C E O thinks the whole thing was a mistake. What a journey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, you can't make this stuff up. It's a real head-scratcher.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, you can't make this stuff up. It's a real head-scratcher.
